html.main:
Core API¶

lux.core.app.execute_from_config(config_file, argv=None, **params)[source]¶

Create and run an Application from a config_file.

This is the function to use when creating the script which runs your web applications:

import lux

if __name__ == '__main__':
    lux.execute_from_config('path.to.config')
Parameters:config_file – the python dotted path to the config file for setting up a new App. The config file should be located in the python module which implements the main application of the web site.
class lux.core.app.Application(callable)[source]¶

The Application is the WSGI callable for serving lux applications.

It is a specialised Extension which collects all extensions of your application and setup the wsgi middleware used by the web server. An App is not usually initialised directly, the higher level execute_from_config() is used instead.

config¶

The configuration dictionary containing all patameters specified in the config_module.

debug¶

debug flag set at runtime via the debug flag:

python myappscript.py serve --debug
handler¶

The WsgiHandler for this application. It is created the first time the callable method of this Application is accessed by the WSGI server.

auth_backend¶

Used by the sessions extension

config_module[source]¶

The configuration file used by this App.

extensions[source]¶

Ordered dictionary of Extension available.

The order is the same as in the EXTENSIONS config parameter.

get_version()[source]¶

Get version of this App. Required by ConsoleParser.

wsgi_request(environ=None, loop=None, path=None, app_handler=None, urlargs=None, **kw)[source]¶

Create a WsgiRequest from a wsgi environ and set the app attribute in the cache. Additional keyed-valued parameters can be inserted.

html_document(request)[source]¶

Build the HTML document.

Usually there is no need to call directly this method. Instead one can use the WsgiRequest.html_document.

commands[source]¶

Load all commands from installed applications

get_command(name, stdout=None, stderr=None)[source]¶

Construct and return a Command for this application

get_usage()[source]¶

Returns the script’s main help text, as a string.

get_parser(with_commands=True, nargs='?', **params)[source]¶

Return a python argparse.ArgumentParser for parsing the command line.

Parameters:
  • with_commands – Include parsing of all commands (default True).
  • params – parameters to pass to the argparse.ArgumentParser constructor.
load_extension(dotted_path)[source]¶

Load an Extension class into this App.

Parameters:dotted_path – python dotted path to the extension.
Returns:an Extension class or None

If the module contains an Extension class named Extension, it will be added to the extension dictionary.

fire(event, *args)[source]¶

Fire an event.

template_full_path(name)[source]¶

Return the template full path or None.

Loops through all extensions in reversed order and check for name within the templates directory

template(name)[source]¶

Load a template from the file system.

The template is must be located in a templates directory of at least one of the extensions included in the :setting:EXTENSIONS` list. The location of the template file is obtained via the template_full_path() method.

If the file is not found an empty string is returned.

context(request, context=None)[source]¶

Load the context dictionary for a request.

This function is called every time a template is rendered via the render_template() method is used and a the wsgi request is passed as key-valued parameter.

The initial context is updated with contribution from all EXTENSIONS which expose the context method.

render_template(name, context=None, request=None, engine=None)[source]¶

Render a template file name with context

html_response(request, template_name, context=None, jscontext=None, title=None, status_code=None)[source]¶

Html response via a template.

Parameters:
  • request – the WsgiRequest
  • template_name – the template file name to load
  • context – optional context dictionary
site_url(path=None)[source]¶

Build the site url from an optional path

media_url(path=None)[source]¶

Build the media url from an optional path

class lux.core.extension.Parameter(name, default, doc)[source]¶

Class for defining a lux parameter within a lux Extension.

Parameters are specified in the _config list of an Extension. For example:

from lux import Extension, Parameter

class MyExtension(Extension):

    _config = [
        Parameter('MYPARAM', 'Hello',
                  'A parameter for my great extension')
        ]
Parameters:
  • name – unique name identifying the parameter which is used to retrieve it from the Application.config dictionary.
  • default – the default value of the parameter. This is the value used by the framework when the parameter is not found in the config file.
  • doc – a documentation string for the parameter.

Parameters are case insensitive.

class lux.core.extension.Extension[source]¶

Base class for extensions including the Application class.

meta¶

The ExtensionMeta data created by the Extension metaclass.

logger¶

The logger instance for this Extension.

middleware(app)[source]¶

Called by application app when creating the middleware.

This method is invoked the first time App.handler attribute is accessed. It must return a list of WSGI middleware or None.

response_middleware(app)[source]¶

Called by application app when creating the response middleware

setup_logger(config, opts)[source]¶

Called by setup() method to setup the logger.

setup(module, params, opts=None)[source]¶

Internal method which prepare the extension for usage.

extra_form_data(request)[source]¶

Must return an iterable over key-value pair of data to add to a Form.

By default it returns an empty tuple.

write(msg='', stream=None)[source]¶

Write msg into stream or sys.stdout

write_err(msg='', stream=None)[source]¶

Write msg into stream or sys.stderr

class lux.core.wrappers.Html(tag, *children, **params)¶

An AsyncString for html content.

The content_type attribute is set to text/html.

Parameters:
  • tag – Set the tag attribute. Must be given and can be None.
  • children – Optional children which will be added via the append() method.
  • params –

    Optional keyed-value parameters including:

    • cn class name or list of class names.
    • attr dictionary of attributes to add.
    • data dictionary of data to add (rendered as HTML data attribute).
    • type type of element, only supported for tags which accept the type attribute (for example the input tag).
addClass(cn)¶

Add the specific class names to the class set and return self.

add_media(request)¶

Invoked just before streaming this content.

It can be used to add media entries to the document.

TODO: more docs

attr(*args)¶

Add the specific attribute to the attribute dictionary with key name and value value and return self.

css(mapping=None)¶

Update the css dictionary if mapping is a dictionary, otherwise return the css value at mapping.

If mapping is not given, return the whole css dictionary if available.

data(*args)¶

Add or retrieve data values for this Html.

flatatt(**attr)¶

Return a string with atributes to add to the tag

get_form_value()¶

Return the value of this Html element when it is contained in a Html form element.

For most element it gets the value attribute.

hasClass(cn)¶

True if cn is a class of self.

hide()¶

Same as jQuery hide method.

removeClass(cn)¶

Remove classes

set_form_value(value)¶

Set the value of this Html element when it is contained in a Html form element. For most element it sets the value attribute.

show()¶

Same as jQuery show method.

tag¶

The tag for this HTML element.

One of div, a, table and so forth. It can be None.

class lux.core.wrappers.route(rule=None, method=None, defaults=None, position=None, **parameters)¶

Decorator to create a child route from a Router method.

Typical usage:

from pulsar.apps.wsgi import Router, route

class View(Router):

    def get(self, request):
        ...

    @route()
    def foo(self, request):
        ...

    @route('/bla', method='post')
    def handle2(self, request):
        ...

In this example, View is the parent router which handle get requests only.

The decorator injects the rule_method attribute to the method it decorates. The attribute is a five elements tuple which contains the Route, the HTTP method, a dictionary of additional parameters, position and the order. Position and order are internal integers used by the Router when deciding the order of url matching. If position is not passed, the order will be given by the position of each method in the Router class.

The decorated method are stored in the Router.rule_methods class attribute.

>>> len(View.rule_methods)
2
>>> View.rule_methods['foo'].rule
/foo
>>> View.rule_methods['foo'].method
'get'
>>> View.rule_methods['handle2'].rule
/bla
>>> View.rule_methods['handle2'].method
'post'

Check the HttpBin example for a sample usage.

Parameters:
  • rule – Optional string for the relative url served by the method which is decorated. If not supplied, the method name is used.
  • method – Optional HTTP method name. Default is get.
  • defaults – Optional dictionary of default variable values used when initialising the Route instance.
  • position – Optional positioning of the router within the list of child routers of the parent router
  • parameters – Additional parameters used when initialising the Router created by this decorator
class lux.core.wrappers.EnvironMixin(environ, name=None)¶

A wrapper around a WSGI_ environ.

Instances of this class have the environ attribute as their only private data. Every other attribute is stored in the environ itself at the pulsar.cache wsgi-extension key.

environ¶

WSGI_ environ dictionary

cache¶

An attribute dictionary of pulsar-specific data stored in the environ at the wsgi-extension key pulsar.cache

connection¶

The Connection handling the request

get(key, default=None)¶

Shortcut to the environ get method.

lux.core.wrappers.html_factory(tag, **defaults)¶

Returns an Html factory function for tag and a given dictionary of defaults parameters. For example:

>>> input_factory = html_factory('input', type='text')
>>> html = input_factory(value='bla')
lux.core.wrappers.get_event_loop()¶

Equivalent to calling get_event_loop_policy().get_event_loop().

class lux.core.wrappers.RouterParam(value=None)¶

A RouterParam is a way to flag a Router parameter so that children can inherit the value if they don’t define their own.

A RouterParam is always defined as a class attribute and it is processed by the Router metaclass and stored in a dictionary available as parameter class attribute.

value¶

The value associated with this RouterParam. THis is the value stored in the Router.parameters dictionary at key given by the class attribute specified in the class definition.

class lux.core.commands.Command(name, app, stdout=None, stderr=None)[source]¶

Signature class for lux commands.

A Command is never initialised directly, instead, the Application.get_command() method is used to retrieve it and executed by its callable method.

name¶

Command name, given by the module name containing the Command.

app¶

The Application running this Command.

stdout¶

The file object corresponding to the output streams of this command.

Default: sys.stdout

stderr¶

The file object corresponding to the error streams of this command.

Default: sys.stderr

get_version()[source]¶

Return the Command version.

By default it is the same version as lux.

run(argv, **params)[source]¶

Run this Command.

This is the only method which needs implementing by subclasses.

run_until_complete(options, **params)[source]¶

Execute the run() method using pulsar asynchronous engine.

Most commands are run using this method.

write(stream='')[source]¶

Write stream to the stdout.

write_err(stream='')[source]¶

Write stream to the stderr.

class lux.core.commands.ConsoleParser[source]¶

A class for parsing the console inputs.

Used as base class for both Command and App
